claim: Americans earn less  than people in certain countries.

supporting.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than in countries like Switzerland and Norway, based on OECD data.

attacks.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than in countries like Switzerland and Norway, based on OECD data.
The OECD data does not account for differences in cost of living, which is significantly higher in Switzerland and Norway compared to the U.S.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), median disposable income in Switzerland and Norway remains higher than in the U.S.
The comparison excludes tax burdens, which are substantially higher in Switzerland and Norway, reducing net income.
Despite higher taxes, social benefits (e.g., healthcare, education) in those countries offset the net income difference for many households.

supporting.text: Average wages in the U.S. are higher than the global average but lower than in some high-income countries such as Luxembourg and Denmark.

attacks.text: Average wages in the U.S. are higher than the global average but lower than in some high-income countries such as Luxembourg and Denmark.
The comparison does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in Luxembourg and Denmark than in the U.S.
Even after adjusting for cost of living, Luxembourg and Denmark still have higher disposable incomes than the U.S. due to stronger social welfare systems.
The U.S. has a much larger and more diverse economy, making average wage comparisons misleading without considering regional variations.
Regional wage disparities in the U.S. are offset by higher wages in tech and finance hubs, which pull the national average up significantly.
The data excludes non-wage compensation like employer-provided healthcare, which is more prevalent in the U.S. than in many high-income countries.

supporting.text: Purchasing power parity-adjusted incomes in the U.S. are surpassed by those in countries like Qatar and Singapore.

attacks.text: Purchasing power parity-adjusted incomes in the U.S. are surpassed by those in countries like Qatar and Singapore.
PPP-adjusted incomes in Qatar and Singapore are skewed by small, wealthy populations and do not reflect typical earnings for most citizens.
Even with skewed distributions, median PPP-adjusted incomes in these countries still exceed U.S. medians, supporting the original claim.
The U.S. has higher disposable incomes after taxes and social transfers compared to Qatar and Singapore.
Disposable income comparisons ignore cost-of-living differences that PPP adjustments account for.

supporting.text: Certain professions in countries like Germany and Australia offer higher salaries than their U.S. counterparts when adjusted for cost of living.

attacks.text: Certain professions in countries like Germany and Australia offer higher salaries than their U.S. counterparts when adjusted for cost of living.
The U.S. has higher average salaries in many high-demand fields like tech and finance compared to Germany and Australia.
Even in tech and finance, cost of living adjustments can make salaries in Germany and Australia more competitive than they appear.
The claim ignores non-salary benefits like healthcare and education, which are often more accessible in Germany and Australia, effectively increasing net income.
Many Americans receive employer-provided healthcare and retirement benefits, which can offset the lack of universal services.

supporting.text: The U.S. has a higher income inequality gap compared to some developed nations, leading to lower median earnings relative to top earners.

attacks.text: The U.S. has a higher income inequality gap compared to some developed nations, leading to lower median earnings relative to top earners.
Median income in the U.S. is still higher than in many developed nations, even with income inequality.
The U.S. median income advantage is concentrated in high-cost areas, reducing real purchasing power for many Americans.
Income inequality measures don't account for non-wage benefits like healthcare and retirement, which are more substantial in some other countries.
Even with benefits considered, U.S. workers face higher out-of-pocket costs that offset these advantages.
The U.S. has higher GDP per capita than most developed nations, suggesting greater earning potential overall.
GDP per capita doesn't reflect income distribution, and the U.S. wealth concentration means most citizens don't benefit proportionally.
